column2: Donald Trumpâ€™s RNC address could mark the start of an American revival
column3: Donald Trump needed to give the speech of his life. He did that, and much more. He laid out an inspiring American Manifesto for our troubled times.
column4: Not surprisingly, from start to finish, it is muscular and bold, leavened only by appeals to racial harmony and pledges of compassion for all. It offers a prominent nod to Bernie Sandersâ€™ supporters in a bid to get some to jump the Democratic ship.
column5: If he wins, and can deliver on his vision, remember this speech. Like Ronald Reaganâ€™s in 1976, Trumpâ€™s 2016 address could mark the start of a desperately needed American revival. As he said near the end, â€œAmerica is back.â€ù Imagine that â€” and pray he is right.

column2: Trump claims GOP nomination, tells struggling Americans 'I am your voice'
column3: Just over a year after Donald J. Trump descended his iconic escalator in Manhattan to announce he was joining a packed field of political veterans seeking the Republican nomination for president, the New York billionaire completed an astonishing and historic political ascent Thursday night in Cleveland, officially claiming his partyâ€™s nomination â€” and declaring to struggling Americans, â€œI am your voice.â€ù
column4: Trump electrified the convention crowd on closing night, with chants of â€œU.S.A.â€ù frequently breaking out as the nominee vowed to put â€œAmerica first.â€ù He used the speech to align his campaign squarely on the side of struggling American workers of all political stripes, as he moved to broaden his appeal beyond the Republican base that largely decided the primaries.
column5: â€œFor more than a year, Donald Trump has been the peopleâ€™s champion, and tonight he is the peopleâ€™s nominee,â€ù she said. â€œâ€_ When my father says heâ€™ll make America great again, he will deliver.â€ù

column2: Was Trump's speech the longest ever?

column2: Donald Trump doesnâ€™t want to make America great. He wants to make it afraid.
column3: Donald Trump is not a candidate the American people would turn to in normal times. Heâ€™s too inexperienced, too eccentric, too volatile, too risky. Voting Trump is burning down the house to collect the insurance money â€” you donâ€™t do it unless things are really, really bad.
column4: Here is Trumpâ€™s problem: Things are not really, really bad. In fact, things are doing much better than when President Obama came into office.
column5: But then, perhaps thereâ€™s truth to his absurd promises: When the crisis is invented, the solution is simpler. Once Trump no longer needs the nation to be afraid, he will stop scaring it. It is his nightmare, and only he can wake us from it.

column2: Emails reveal Hillaryâ€™s shocking pay-for-play scheme
column3: Hillary Clinton put the State Department up for sale, with top aides pulling strings and doing favors for fat-cat donors to the Clinton Foundation â€” including a shady billionaire, according to smoking-gun emails released Tuesday.
column4: The stunning revelations include how wealthy contributors seeking influence or prestigious government gigs could fork over piles of cash to get access to Clintonâ€™s inner circle, including top aides Huma Abedin and Cheryl Mills.
column5: â€œThey are communications between her aides and the presidentâ€™s personal aide, and indeed the recommendation was for one of the secretaryâ€™s former staffers who was not employed by the foundation,â€ù he added.

column2: Newly released emails raise questions about relationship between State Department and Clinton Foundation
column3: Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton. The conservative watchdog group Judicial Watch on Tuesday released an additional 296 pages of emails from Hillary Clinton, including 44 that it said were not previously disclosed to the State Department by the former secretary of state.
column4: Among the emails were some that raised questions about the relationship between the Clinton Foundation and the State Department.
column5: Neither of these emails involve the secretary or relate to the Foundation's work, Josh Schwerin, a Clinton campaign spokesman, said in an emailed statement to CNN. "They are communications between her aides and the president's personal aide, and indeed the recommendation was for one of the secretary's former staffers who was not employed by the Foundation."

column2: From Whitewater to Benghazi: A Clinton-Scandal Primer
column3: Oops, never mind! Thatâ€™s FBI Director James Comeyâ€™s new message to Congress and, by extension, the American public on Sunday. A little over a week ago, Comey shook the presidential election with a letter to the chairs of several congressional committees, announcing that the FBI had found a new tranche of emails pertinent to its investigation into Hillary Clintonâ€™s use of a private email server while secretary of state. The emails came from an unrelated case, he saidâ€”since widely reported to be an investigation into alleged sexts to a teenager from Anthony Weiner, whose estranged wife is a top Clinton aideâ€”and there was no timeline for finishing the review. The revelation gave new life to the struggling Donald Trump campaign, which seized on the matter as proof of Clintonâ€™s bad judgment. Her poll numbers, as well as her favorability figures and Democratic enthusiasm, sagged. New leaks began dripping out of the FBI on a daily basis, along with allegations that the bureau was trying to tip the election toward Trump. The Clinton campaign demanded that Comey say more, but no information was forthcoming.
column4: But in a new letter on Sunday, Comey revealed that FBI agents had been working â€œaround the clockâ€ù to look at the emails. â€œDuring that process, we reviewed all of the communications that were to or from Hillary Clinton while she was Secretary of State,â€ù Comey wrote. â€œBased on our review, we have not changed our conclusions that we expressed in July with respect to Secretary Clinton.â€ù In other words, it was all much ado about nothing. Comeyâ€™s recommended in July was that although Clinton had been â€œextremely carelessâ€ù with classified information, there was no grounds for charging her with a crime. Put more bluntly, the FBI altered the course of the presidential campaign for what amounts to a fire drill. This doesnâ€™t mean the email story is gone entirely. On Friday, a new release showed that in at least one case Clinton forwarded emails to her daughter, Chelsea Clinton, that the government now labels classified. The chain in question was released on November 4, as part of the ongoing release of Clintonâ€™s emails from her time as secretary of state. The messages appeared to be related to climate talks in Copenhagen in December 2009, although they were redacted so that it is impossible to tell. They were sent to an email address that Chelsea Clinton used under an alias, â€œDiane Reynolds.â€ù It was not marked classified at the time. The emails and the private server through which they operated have been a defining story of the Clinton campaign. In March 2015, The New York Times first reported on Clintonâ€™s use of a private email address and a private server during her time at Foggy Bottom. The story has dogged Clinton ever since, raising questions about her judgment and trustworthiness.
column5: Who? Both Cheryl Mills and Huma Abedin are among Clintonâ€™s longest-serving and closest aides. Abedin remains involved in her campaign (and sheâ€™s also married to Anthony Weiner). When? January 2009-February 2013 How serious is it? This is arcane stuff, to be sure. There are questions about conflict of interestâ€”such as whether Teneo clients might have benefited from special treatment by the State Department while Abedin worked for both. To a great extent, this is just an extension of the tangle of conflicts presented by the Clinton Foundation and the many overlapping roles of Bill and Hillary Clinton. Sidney Blumenthal What? A former journalist, Blumenthal was a top aide in the second term of the Bill Clinton administration and helped on messaging during the bad old days. He served as an adviser to Hillary Clintonâ€™s 2008 presidential campaign, and when she took over the State Department, she sought to hire Blumenthal. Obama aides, apparently still smarting over his role in attacks on candidate Obama, refused the request, so Clinton just sought out his counsel informally. At the same time, Blumenthal was drawing a check from the Clinton Foundation.

column2: Trump warns North Korea will be "met with fire and fury"
column3: President Trump addressed the ongoing crisis between the U.S. and North Korea at a briefing on opioids in New Jersey on Tuesday, issuing a stern warning to the regime for its continued provocations.
column4: North Korea best not make any more threats to the United States, warned Mr. Trump from his golf club in Bedminster.
column5: The U.S. in May successfully carried out its first-ever missile defense test to intercept an ICBM-type weapon, but other tests have had mixed results.

column2: North Korea Can Put a Nuclear Weapon on a Missile, Officials Believe
column3: WASHINGTON â€” U.S. intelligence agencies have made an assessment that North Korea has constructed a nuclear weapon small enough to fit on a missile, according to a U.S. official briefed on the assessment.
column4: The U.S. belief that North Korea has reached this milestone was first reported by The Washington Post, which said that the assessment came from a Defense Intelligence Agency analysis completed last month.
column5: The official said, however, that this does not mean that North Korea has fielded a nuclear-tipped intercontinental ballistic missile. The North Koreans still have to establish that they can deliver a weapon accurately that survives reentry.

column2: Trump Warns North Korea of â€˜Fire and Fury Like the World Has Never Seenâ€™
column3: Speaking at his golf club in Bedminster, N.J., President Trump warned today, â€œNorth Korea best not make any more threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen.â€ù
column4: The statement comes in a series of escalating threats and provocative moves by North Koreaâ€™s regime. The Washington Post is reporting that U.S. intelligence officials assess that North Korea has successfully produced a miniaturized nuclear warhead that can fit inside its missiles. Japanâ€™s defense minister said â€œsecurity threats have entered a new stage.â€ù Yesterday, North Korea said it would use its nuclear weapons only against the United States, and said it would â€œunder no circumstancesâ€ù negotiate on its nuclear and missile weapons programs. Also yesterday, Fox News reported that U.S. spy agencies detected the North Korean military â€œloading two anti-ship cruise missiles on a patrol boat on the countryâ€™s east coast just days ago,â€ù suggesting another missile test may be on the way. Late last month, North Korea test-fired a missile that could hit much of the continental United States.
column5: Unless China suddenly applies a great deal more pressure to Pyongyang, either this president or the next will face a devastating choice among bad options: accept a nuclear-armed North Korea that can strike American cities, fight a conventional war before those ballistic missiles are operational, or fight a nuclear war somewhere down the road.

column2: Ten inconsistencies in Donald Trump's big foreign policy address
column3: For a speech purporting to challenge Washingtonâ€™s accepted wisdom, there was much that was familiar about Donald Trumpâ€™s first big foreign policy address, not least the customary certainty of its delivery.
column4: A call to challenge radical Islam through â€œphilosophical struggleâ€ù as well as military force might even have come from the lips of Barack Obama. Certainly no mainstream Republican would ever disagree with the somewhat motherhood-and-apple-pie exhortation for US presidents to view the world â€œthrough the clear lens of American interestsâ€ù.
column5: It is perhaps unfair, however, to dwell too closely on textual analysis of a speech clearly written by a number of people. â€œWe will no longer surrender this country or its people to the false song of globalismâ€ù is a powerful line, but it does not sound very much like it was written by the same man who told a rally in Pennsylvania on Monday: â€œDo I look like a president? How handsome am I?â€ù

column2: Trump fails to impress foreign-policy experts
column3: In his address to an elite, invitation-only Washington foreign policy audience Wednesday, Donald Trump promised that, as president, he would restore a â€œcoherentâ€ù vision to Americaâ€™s role in the world.
column4: But across the ideological spectrum, and even among natural allies, Trumpâ€™s speech received a failing grade for coherence and drew snickering and scorn from foreign policy insiders who remain unconvinced that Trump is up to the job.
column5: â€œRonald Reagan must be rolling over in his grave,â€ù Graham tweeted.

column2: Itâ€™s what was left unsaid in Trumpâ€™s speech that matters most
column3: What was important about Donald Trumpâ€™s much anticipated foreign policy speech Wednesday is what he didnâ€™t say. There was no mention by the self-declared Republican Partyâ€™s presumptive presidential nominee of his determination to build a wall between Mexico and the United States and get the Mexican government to pay for it.
column4: There was only a passing reference to his frequent criticism of illegal immigrants, the theme that helped launch his presidential campaign last summer.
column5: That was not only vintage Trump, but a precursor of what lies ahead if Mr. Trump, indeed, wins the nomination.

column2: The Cuban Embargo Is One of the Least Effective Foreign Policy Initiatives in U.S. History
column3: In what one longtime Cuba watcher is calling â€œthe biggest day for U.S.-Cuban relations in 50 years,â€ù the two governments announced a prisoner exchange today that removes some of the largest impediments to full diplomatic relations between the longtime adversaries. Both President Obama and Cuban President RaÃºl Castro are due to make statements later today, and according to ABC News, â€œThe White House is indicating the beginning of new talks on everything from travel restrictions to eventual lifting of the Cuban embargo in place since John F. Kennedy was president.â€ù
column4: Alan Gross, an American who was arrested and charged with â€œacts against the independence and territorial integrity of the stateâ€ù in 2009 while attempting to deliver communications equipment to religious groups on the island as a subcontractor for USAID, has been released and is now en route back to the U.S. Gross was reportedly in poor health, and Obama had suggested earlier this month that his release would â€œremove an impediment to more constructive relations.â€ù
column5: (Update, 12:38 p.m. The measures announced by the White House on Wednesday include many of the steps mentioned above, including more travel licenses, allowing the export of goods to private Cuban enterprises, and the sale of communications equipment and authorizing U.S. credit and debit card use by U.S. travelers to Cuba. The State Department will also be reviewing Cubaâ€™s state terrorism designation. More dramatically, the U.S. is re-establishing an embassy in Havana in the next few months and beginning talks on restoring full diplomatic relations. This was a lot faster and more sweeping than expected.)

column3: Here are four names, long forgotten, that should be noted today: Armando Alejandre, Carlos Costa, Pablo Morales, and Mario de la PeÃ±a. They were three U.S. citizens and one permanent resident. They were pilots with Brothers to the Rescue, the outfit that looks for Cuban refugees, as they are stranded or desperate on the sea.
column4: On February 24, 1996, the four pilots were shot out of the sky by the Cuban dictatorshipâ€™s forces. The planes were in international airspace at the time. The Castro government killed the men simply because they were trying to help innocent Cubans.
column5: The Cuban government is not legitimate, and never has been. It is a one-party dictatorship with a gulag, an archipelago of prisons into which democrats and dissidents are thrown. We hope that the new American policy â€” Obamaâ€™s policy â€” does not benefit the Cuban dictatorship and harm Cuban democrats. We fear that yesterday was a good day for the Castros and a bad day for the Cuban people, and for American foreign policy.

column2: Obamacare Customers Face Big Price Hikes Next Year
column3: WASHINGTON â€• The rate hikes are coming. Eight days before the beginning of a crucial enrollment season for the Affordable Care Actâ€™s health insurance exchange marketplaces, federal officials announced Monday how much prices are going up.
column4: The gist: a lot. But like everything Obamacare, itâ€™s not that simple. The lawâ€™s financial assistance will protect millions of lower-income families from these premium increases, and others can find relief by switching to different plans next year to save money. There will be losers, however, mostly among higher-income households that find canâ€™t avoid the premium increases and are forced to either pay more or go without health insurance.
column5: But high sticker prices, especially for those who receive small subsidies or none at all, threaten to discourage people who need the coverage the least: those healthy individuals that insurers covet because they pay in and seldom draw down. If these exchanges canâ€™t find the right balance between costs and revenues, insurers will be less willing to sell policies on them, and customers will be less willing to buy that coverage, which would undermine the system for everyone using it.

column2: Republicans blast ObamaCare after premium hike announcement
column3: Republicans blasted the White House on Monday after President Obamaâ€™s administration announced premiums for his signature health care law will rise sharply next year and many consumers would be down to just one insurer.
column4: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump, while campaigning in Tampa, Fla., emphatically declared ObamaCare â€œover.â€ù
column5: Enrollment has been lower than initially projected, and insurers say patients turned out to be sicker than expected. Moreover, a complex internal system to help stabilize premiums has not worked as hoped for.
